article.title: A Leaky Pipe Dream? A Study of Gender Differences in Undergraduate Physics

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure illustrate about the relationship between science capital, habitus, and science outcomes in a particular field of study?
choices: Students with high levels of science capital will always achieve high grades, regardless of their habitus.
A student\'s habitus is solely determined by their science capital.
Habitus acts as a filter, preventing some students from accessing science capital.
Science capital and habitus interact to influence a student\'s practices and appreciation of the field, ultimately impacting their science outcomes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does the density plot show in the GPE distribution of male and female physics students?
choices: Male students have a higher concentration of GPEs in the higher range (6-9) compared to female students.
Female students have a higher concentration of GPEs in the higher range (6-9) compared to female students.
There is no observable difference in the GPE distribution between male and female students.
Both male and female students show a similar peak in GPEs around 5, but female students have a wider spread of scores.

multiple_choice_question.text: What general trend can be observed in the subject selection of physics students in their second year, as depicted in the odds ratio plot?
choices: Female students are generally more likely to enroll in physical science subjects compared to male students.
Male students are generally more likely to enroll in life science subjects compared to female students.
Female students are generally more likely to enroll in life science subjects, while male students are more likely to enroll in physical science subjects.
There are no significant differences in the subject enrollment patterns of male and female physics students in their second year.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the figure illustrate about the relationship between GPE, gender, and grades in first- and second-year physics courses?
choices: Male students consistently outperform female students across all GPE levels and physics courses.
Female students consistently outperform male students across all GPE levels and physics courses.
Gender differences in physics performance are negligible and consistent across all GPE levels and physics courses.

Gender differences in performance vary significantly between courses, with a tendency for male students with low GPE scores to outperform female counterparts in some first-year courses, while this trend diminishes or reverses in second-year courses.
